# Knowledge Base: Parallel Channels & Rectangles

## DOCUMENT METADATA

```yaml
Document:
  title: "Parallel Channels / Rectangles"
  author: "Chart Champions"
  year: "2019"
  edition: "Cheat Sheet"
  methodology_family: "Price Action"
  asset_focus: "Crypto"
  total_pages: "16"
```

# Textual Hierarchy & Theory

## Parallel Channels/Rectangles

> **Definition: Parallel Channel** - A price pattern formed by at least 4 touches (2 on the bottom, 2 on top) where price moves between parallel trendlines.

> **Definition: Rectangle** - A specific type of parallel channel where the trendlines are horizontal (sideways channel).

> **Definition: Measured Move** - The vertical distance of the channel height, which is projected from the breakout point to determine price targets.

> **Pro Tip:** "There should be at least 4 touches, 2 on the bottom 2 on top. Technically the pattern should be viewed as neutral as price can break up or down, but trading the break in the overall trend direction yields better results."

> **Pro Tip:** "Look for an increase in volume upon the breakout."

> **Pro Tip:** "Never ever delete a channel from your chart when broken because the old channel will be broken and come back as a new channel. The old channel acts as a support."

> **Pro Tip:** "Daniel likes to draw his channels from the respected bottom candle closes to the respected top candle closes but if there is an important factor such as S/R flip, he goes for a wick as well. There is no hard rules, see what is respected more."

## Day Trading Channels

> **Pro Tip:** "I will generally trade a channel from bottom to top, or top to bottom with a take profit set at the mid point of the channel. I like to take 50% profit at the mid point and move stops up to breakeven. I will compound the trade if there is a close above the midpoint."

## Early Signs a Range Could Form

> **Pro Tip:** "You can get early signs a range may form. If you have a move from a major support to a major resistance, and the price starts to close back under the resistance line then it appears the resistance is holding, and you could short back down to the bottom of the range support, which in turn will start to create a channel."

## Price Formed a Well Defined Channel

> **Pro Tip:** "Deviations from the range. Price gets outside of the range, but instead of getting follow through, gets series of Lower highs and Lower Lows to get back inside of the range. Once back inside the range after a deviation one would enter a trade to the side of the channel, taking profit in the middle."

# ðŸ“Š Chart Analysis: General Channel Setup (Page 2)

**Metadata:** 
- Timeframe: Not specified (appears to be intraday)
- Asset: Not specified
- Indicator Parameters: None (pure price action)

**Spatial Annotation Map:**
- "Channel height" labels are placed vertically between the parallel trendlines
- "TP1" label is positioned at the bottom channel line
- "TP2" label is positioned at the measured move extension below the channel
- "1", "2", "3" labels indicate the three anchor points for drawing the channel

**The Narrative Flow (Chronological):**
1. Price forms a channel with 4 touches (2 on top, 2 on bottom)
2. Price breaks out of the channel to the downside
3. TP1 is set at the bottom of the channel
4. After breaking the channel, stop loss is moved to the midpoint of the channel
5. TP2 is set at the measured move (channel height) extended from the breakout point

**Hard Data Extraction:**
- Channel height: [UNCLEAR numerical value]
- TP1: Bottom of channel
- TP2: Channel height below breakout point

# ðŸ“Š Chart Analysis: Day Trading Channel (Page 3)

**Metadata:**
- Timeframe: Intraday (day trading)
- Asset: Not specified
- Indicator Parameters: None (pure price action)

**Spatial Annotation Map:**
- The chart shows a channel with top and bottom trendlines
- Price is shown moving from bottom to top of the channel

**The Narrative Flow (Chronological):**
1. Price forms a channel with clear support and resistance
2. Trader enters long at channel support
3. 50% profit is taken at the midpoint of the channel
4. Stop loss is moved to breakeven after partial profit
5. Remaining position is held to the top of the channel

**Hard Data Extraction:**
- Take profit at 50% (midpoint of channel)
- Stop loss moved to breakeven after partial profit

# ðŸ“Š Chart Analysis: Early Range Formation (Page 4)

**Metadata:**
- Timeframe: Daily
- Asset: Not specified
- Indicator Parameters: "Daily Level" support/resistance marked

**Spatial Annotation Map:**
- "Daily Level" labels mark major support and resistance levels
- Price is shown moving from support to resistance

**The Narrative Flow (Chronological):**
1. Price moves from major support to major resistance
2. Price closes back under the resistance line
3. This confirms resistance is holding
4. Short trade is taken back to the bottom of the range support

**Hard Data Extraction:**
- Daily support/resistance levels marked

# ðŸ“Š Chart Analysis: Well-Defined Channel with Deviations (Page 5)

**Metadata:**
- Timeframe: Daily
- Asset: Not specified
- Indicator Parameters: "Daily Level" support/resistance marked

**Spatial Annotation Map:**
- "Daily Level" labels mark the channel boundaries
- Arrows show deviations outside the channel and subsequent return

**The Narrative Flow (Chronological):**
1. Price forms a well-defined channel between daily support and resistance
2. Price gets outside the range (deviation)
3. Instead of follow-through, price forms lower highs and lower lows
4. Price returns inside the channel
5. Entry is made to the side of the channel with profit taken at the middle

**Hard Data Extraction:**
- Multiple deviations shown
- Channel respected after deviations

# ðŸ“Š Chart Analysis: Parallel Channel Drawing (Page 6)

**Metadata:**
- Timeframe: Not specified
- Asset: Not specified
- Indicator Parameters: None

**Spatial Annotation Map:**
- "1", "2", "3" labels show the sequence for drawing the channel
- Channel is drawn with parallel lines

**The Narrative Flow (Chronological):**
1. Click on point 1 (first anchor)
2. Drag to point 2 (second anchor)
3. Click on point 3 (third anchor) to complete the channel
4. In an upward trending channel, the middle and top serve as price targets for longs

**Hard Data Extraction:**
- 3 anchor points required to draw channel
- Points labeled 1, 2, 3

# ðŸ“Š Chart Analysis: Upward Sloping Channel (Page 7)

**Metadata:**
- Timeframe: Not specified
- Asset: Not specified
- Indicator Parameters: None

**Spatial Annotation Map:**
- "1", "2", "3" labels show channel drawing points
- "Price hits top of the channel" label at resistance
- "Price hits mid point" label at channel midpoint

**The Narrative Flow (Chronological):**
1. Channel is drawn with upward slope
2. Price hits top of channel
3. Target is hit for the trade
4. Price hits midpoint and retraces
5. Author suggests taking longs at the bottom rather than shorts at the top in upward channels

**Hard Data Extraction:**
- Channel has upward slope
- Midpoint and top serve as targets

# ðŸ“Š Chart Analysis: Upward Channel Within Higher Timeframe Channel (Page 8)

**Metadata:**
- Timeframe: Higher timeframe (daily) with lower timeframe channel
- Asset: Not specified
- Indicator Parameters: None

**Spatial Annotation Map:**
- Larger horizontal channel contains a smaller upward sloping channel
- "1", "2", "3" labels show channel drawing points

**The Narrative Flow (Chronological):**
1. Price ranges from low to high in a higher timeframe channel
2. As price moves up, it forms an upward sloping channel
3. Price starts to move upward as expected, creating a new upward channel
4. Price reaches resistance at the midpoint of the higher timeframe channel
5. The upward channel is used for long trades to the top

**Hard Data Extraction:**
- Higher timeframe sideways channel
- Lower timeframe upward channel within it

# ðŸ“Š Chart Analysis: Channel Trading Example (Page 9)

**Metadata:**
- Timeframe: Not specified
- Asset: Not specified
- Indicator Parameters: None

**Spatial Annotation Map:**
- "Support = long" labels at channel bottom
- "Resistance = short" labels at channel top
- "Close back inside the range = short" label after deviation

**The Narrative Flow (Chronological):**
1. Price forms a channel with clear support and resistance
2. Support acts as long entry point
3. Resistance acts as short entry point
4. Price closes outside channel range (support flips to resistance)
5. Price closes back inside range after deviation
6. Trade is taken in direction of the range (short when closing back inside)

**Hard Data Extraction:**
- Support/resistance levels marked
- S/R flip after breakout

# ðŸ“Š Chart Analysis: Old Channel as Support (Page 10)

**Metadata:**
- Timeframe: Daily
- Asset: BTCUSD (15/08/2019)
- Indicator Parameters: None

**Spatial Annotation Map:**
- "Previous smaller time frame channel acts as support" label
- "Short top of the range" label at resistance
- "Long bottom of the range" label at support

**The Narrative Flow (Chronological):**
1. Sideways range forms after price rise
2. Previous smaller timeframe channel acts as support
3. Short trade taken at top of range with profit at midpoint
4. Long trade taken at bottom of range with profit at midpoint
5. Price closes outside range, then retests channel resistance as support
6. Price continues upward in impulse wave

**Hard Data Extraction:**
- BTCUSD 15/08/2019
- Multiple timeframe analysis

# ðŸ“Š Chart Analysis: Old Channel Support (Page 11)

**Metadata:**
- Timeframe: Daily
- Asset: BTCUSD (15/06/2019)
- Indicator Parameters: None

**Spatial Annotation Map:**
- "Sideways channel consolidation" label
- "Price has moved away from channel resistance" label
- "Price again finds support on the mid point" label

**The Narrative Flow (Chronological):**
1. Price forms sideways channel consolidation
2. Price moves away from channel resistance
3. When price retraces, it finds support from old channel
4. Price finds support again at midpoint of old parallel channel
5. Old channel is respected multiple times as support

**Hard Data Extraction:**
- BTCUSD 15/06/2019
- Multiple retests of old channel

# ðŸ“Š Chart Analysis: Channel Drawing Techniques (Page 12)

**Metadata:**
- Timeframe: Daily
- Asset: BTCUSD (05/2019 to 10/2019)
- Indicator Parameters: None

**Spatial Annotation Map:**
- "Top of channel is marked by highest candle close" label
- "Partial rise confirmed when price closes back below mid" label
- "Old resistance flips into support" label

**The Narrative Flow (Chronological):**
1. Channel drawn from highest candle close to support
2. Price closes above midpoint, long trade taken to high of range
3. Price closes back below midpoint, confirming partial rise
4. Short trade taken after closing below midpoint
5. Old resistance becomes new support

**Hard Data Extraction:**
- BTCUSD 05/2019 to 10/2019
- Midpoint of channel as key level

# ðŸ“Š Chart Analysis: Fibonacci Channels (Page 13)

**Metadata:**
- Timeframe: Higher timeframe (daily)
- Asset: BTCUSD (05/2019 to 10/2019)
- Indicator Parameters: Fibonacci levels (0, 0.236, 0.382, 0.5, 0.618, 0.66, 0.786, 1)

**Spatial Annotation Map:**
- Fibonacci levels marked on the right side of the chart
- Channel drawn from high to low

**The Narrative Flow (Chronological):**
1. Channel drawn from high to low with Fibonacci levels
2. Fibonacci levels (0.236, 0.382, 0.5, 0.618, etc.) act as support/resistance
3. Price respects Fibonacci levels within the channel
4. Channel is used exclusively on higher timeframes

**Hard Data Extraction:**
- Fibonacci levels: 0, 0.236, 0.382, 0.5, 0.618, 0.66, 0.786, 1
- BTCUSD 05/2019 to 10/2019

# ðŸ“Š Chart Analysis: Long Term Channels (Page 14)

**Metadata:**
- Timeframe: 1+ day (long-term)
- Asset: IOTUSD (11/2018 to 7/2019)
- Indicator Parameters: 0.618, 1.618, 0, 1, 2, 2.618 levels

**Spatial Annotation Map:**
- "1", "2", "3" labels for channel drawing
- "0.618", "1.618", "0", "1", "2", "2.618" labels for Fibonacci extensions

**The Narrative Flow (Chronological):**
1. Long-term channel drawn on 1+ year data
2. Channel points (0.618, 1.618, 0, 1, 2, 2.618) are respected as support/resistance
3. Closing outside the channel signals potential end of trend
4. Used to determine when long-term trends may be ending

**Hard Data Extraction:**
- IOTUSD 11/2018 to 7/2019
- Fibonacci levels: 0.618, 1.618, 0, 1, 2, 2.618

# ðŸ“Š Chart Analysis: Fib Channel Extension (Page 15)

**Metadata:**
- Timeframe: Not specified
- Asset: XBTUSD (9/2019)
- Indicator Parameters: 0, 0.618, 1, 1.618, 2, 2.618

**Spatial Annotation Map:**
- "0", "0.618", "1", "1.618", "2", "2.618" labels marking Fibonacci levels
- Channel drawn from peak to valley to secondary peak

**The Narrative Flow (Chronological):**
1. Channel drawn from major peak (1) to major valley (2)
2. Third click placed on significant peak (3)
3. Width from 1-2 trendline to point 3 creates Fib channel
4. Fib levels used to calculate price targets for bounces
5. Valid channel requires 0.618 or 1 trendlines to be respected

**Hard Data Extraction:**
- XBTUSD 9/2019
- Fibonacci levels: 0, 0.618, 1, 1.618, 2, 2.618

# ðŸ“Š Chart Analysis: Fib Channel Extension Example (Page 16)

**Metadata:**
- Timeframe: 1+ day
- Asset: XBTUSD (1/2019-10/2019)
- Indicator Parameters: 0.618, 1.618, 0, 1, 2, 2.618

**Spatial Annotation Map:**
- "0.618" and "1.618" labels marking key Fibonacci levels
- "Exact touch which gave 10% bounce" label at 0.618 level

**The Narrative Flow (Chronological):**
1. Price forms a well-respected Fib channel extension
2. Price touches the 0.618 level exactly
3. This touch results in a 10% bounce
4. Channel is validated by price respecting the Fibonacci levels

**Hard Data Extraction:**
- XBTUSD 1/2019-10/2019
- 10% bounce from 0.618 level
- Fibonacci levels: 0.618, 1.618, 0, 1, 2, 2.618

# Strategic Logic

```yaml
Strategy Name: General Channel Breakout
Direction: Long/Short (depending on trend direction)
Conditions:
  - IF: Price forms parallel channel with at least 4 touches (2 top, 2 bottom)
  - AND: Price breaks channel boundary with increased volume
  - AND: Break occurs in direction of overall trend
Triggers:
  - ENTRY: Break of channel boundary
  - STOP LOSS: Beyond channel boundary (opposite side)
  - TAKE PROFIT: 
    - TP1: Opposite channel boundary
    - TP2: Measured move (channel height) extended from breakout
    - TP3: Maximum target as channel height extended further in breakout direction
```

```yaml
Strategy Name: Day Trading Channel
Direction: Both (Long at support, Short at resistance)
Conditions:
  - IF: Well-defined channel with clear support/resistance
  - AND: Price approaches channel boundary
  - AND: Channel has been respected multiple times
Triggers:
  - ENTRY: 
    - Long at channel support
    - Short at channel resistance
  - STOP LOSS: Beyond channel boundary
  - TAKE PROFIT:
    - 50% at channel midpoint
    - Remaining position to opposite channel boundary
    - Stop loss moved to breakeven after partial profit
```

```yaml
Strategy Name: Range Formation Entry
Direction: Both (Short from resistance, Long from support)
Conditions:
  - IF: Price moves from major support to major resistance
  - AND: Price closes back under resistance line
  - AND: Resistance is holding (confirmed by multiple tests)
Triggers:
  - ENTRY: Short when price closes back under resistance
  - STOP LOSS: Above recent swing high
  - TAKE PROFIT: At bottom of range support
```

```yaml
Strategy Name: Deviation from Range
Direction: Both (returning to channel)
Conditions:
  - IF: Price gets outside channel range
  - AND: No follow-through after breakout
  - AND: Price forms lower highs and lower lows (for upside deviation) or higher highs and higher lows (for downside deviation)
  - AND: Price returns inside channel
Triggers:
  - ENTRY: When price re-enters channel after deviation
  - STOP LOSS: Beyond deviation extreme
  - TAKE PROFIT: At channel midpoint
```

```yaml
Strategy Name: Fibonacci Channel
Direction: Both (Long at Fib support, Short at Fib resistance)
Conditions:
  - IF: Channel drawn on higher timeframe (daily+)
  - AND: Fibonacci levels (0.236, 0.382, 0.5, 0.618, etc.) are respected as S/R
  - AND: Price approaches Fibonacci level with confluence
Triggers:
  - ENTRY: At respected Fibonacci level
  - STOP LOSS: Beyond the Fibonacci level
  - TAKE PROFIT: At next Fibonacci level in direction of trade
```

```yaml
Strategy Name: Long Term Channel Reversal
Direction: Both (based on trend direction)
Conditions:
  - IF: Long-term channel (1+ year data) is well-respected
  - AND: Price closes outside channel boundary
  - AND: Break is confirmed (sustained close outside channel)
  - AND: Log scale used for volatile assets
Triggers:
  - ENTRY: When price closes outside channel boundary
  - STOP LOSS: Back inside channel
  - TAKE PROFIT: Measured move of channel height extended from breakout
```

# Mathematical & Tabular Data

## Channel Height Measurement Formula

The measured move is calculated as:

$$\text{Channel Height} = \text{Top Channel Boundary} - \text{Bottom Channel Boundary}$$

## Fibonacci Channel Extension Levels

| Level | Value |
|-------|-------|
| 0     | 0.000 |
| 0.236 | 0.236 |
| 0.382 | 0.382 |
| 0.5   | 0.500 |
| 0.618 | 0.618 |
| 0.66  | 0.660 |
| 0.786 | 0.786 |
| 1     | 1.000 |
| 1.618 | 1.618 |
| 2     | 2.000 |
| 2.618 | 2.618 |

## Price Target Calculations

For breakout trades:
- TP1 = Opposite channel boundary
- TP2 = Breakout point Â± Channel Height
- TP3 = Breakout point Â± (2 Ã— Channel Height)

For channel trading:
- Partial Profit = Channel Midpoint
- Full Profit = Opposite channel boundary
